Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2009 09:09PM - edited Dec 28, 2009 09:10PM by Judiiiii Hi.  If you should develop Hand/Foot Syndrome, as many do, make sure you show your hands and feet to your onc - he/she will be able to tell if you should stop or lower the dose.  I know of several women who had to be hospitalized for HF syndrome and were unable to walk.  Mine was bad, too, but I used Bag Balm faithfully twice per day and it helped more than anything else that I tried.  It comes in a green square metal container and can be found at all drugstores.  Start using it twice daily at the first sign of HF Syndrome.  I loved Xeloda and was on it for 4 years!  Best of luck!  Judi

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2009 06:38PM Judiiiii wrote: Rhonda, sorry 'bout your losing connection.  So frustrating!  Re the reliability of tumor markers:  It varies a whole lot.  For some women/men, they are not reliable at all.  For some of us, though (like me), they are totally reliable.  Indeed, I have refused scans for the last two years, but I do so knowing that my tumor markers will "let me know" when it is time to change treatments.  My onc agrees - not as wholeheartedly as I do, but I'm the boss.  I've had mets for 8 years and my tumor markers have always been right on as to what was going on. With tumor markers, though, it is important to look for trends of a few months, rather than a stand-alone number - i.e., compare TMs from one time to the next few. Also, one person's TM might be 2000, while another's might be 50, and yet their cancers could be of the same burden.  We differ in so many ways.  Some cancers just shed more than others and, thus, higher TMs. Hope this helps.  Take care....   Judi

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2009 08:50PM - edited Dec 30, 2009 09:31PM by Judiiiii Dawn, I do not believe those stats, not at all.  They are so contrary to every stat published on reputable sites.  It is a wonky site - too many ads - to be believable and, again, just so inflated.  I found the same statement on Medscape - a reputable site.  However, the wrongdiagnosis.com site, as you reference in your post, made a big mistake!  They included the word "metastatic" and that is wrong.  The word "metastatic" should be deleted from the wrongdiagnosis.com site.  They obviously meant them as stats for women with NO METASTASES.   The survival rates for metastatic vs. not metastatic are vastly different and wrongdiagnosis.com put in the wrong survival rates.  The 20-year survival rate for metastatic breast cancer is something like only 5% - regardless of the size. I have written to the web site and asked them to correct their statement.  One needs to be very very very careful about believing whatever you read on the Internet. Judi Diagnosis: 9/23/2001, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2-

I'm very careful when it comes to Googling.  Up until two years ago, I was a health sciences researcher for the Dept. of Veterans Affairs and conducted studies and published papers (even a smallish study on the factors that contribute to women's decision on what type of treatment to pursue if they had options - the majority chose whatever their onc suggested, regardless of the fact that the survival rates were the same - not surprising, but the study was fun to do).  Anyway, my education and career were research based and I learned not to trust anything I read, but, rather, to read at least the abstracts of studies to determine whether the study results were valid and reliable.  So, I generally take with a grain of salt whatever results I get from googling, unless I am familiar with the author(s). Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2010 02:07PM Judiiiii wrote: Hi Nicole.  Your experience with your local onc sounds horrific!  How dare he conduct himself in such a manner.  Unforgiveable!!  I don't know your U of M onc, but it sounds like you have a great relationship.  Ask any question of me you like.  Unfortunately, my recall, after 8+ years of chemo sucks. I've had very little radiation - just 2 weeks to my spine and 2 weeks to my eye for eye mets.  I got tired, but mostly tired of having to go everyday. I've lost count of the number of chemo cycles.  I was dx'd at Stage IV over 8 years ago and have tried nearly every chemo available.  I responded to all of them - for varying lengths of time.  I was never really NED or in remission.  A lot of women experience NED, even at Stage IV, but I was not one of them.  Unfortunately, there is only one or maybe two chemos left to try, but I've had a great 8 years - well, the first 6 years were great, but not the last two when I had to quit work.  All of a sudden, my markers were out of sight and I lost most of my energy - walking became difficult and still is.  I quit work 2 years ago, but for the 6 years prior to that, I worked hard as a health services research specialist and loved it, travelled a whole bunch, and just pretty much lived my life as I did pre-BC.  Alas, things are different now, but I still consider myself blessed and lucky to have had 6 great years, despite being on chemo nearly all of that time (I got a couple of years on anti-hormonals). Your baby is adorable!  I can't imagine chasing around such a wee one, but I know that it is worth it.  I am single and mom to a 13-year old devil in a fur dress - my cat.  She's all I can manage! I, too, take Xanax at night.  Generally works well, but I find myself not wanting to go to sleep and finally turn off the TV at around 2 a.m. and don't wake up till about noon.  It shouldn't matter - don't have to go anywhere, but I'd like to get up earlier. I hurt my foot and knee about 2 months ago and have had to use a walker since then.  But they are getting better - finally.  My knee kept buckling and it is scary.  My best friend comes over 1X per week to straighten up and run errands for me.  I am forever thankful for her. What treatment are you on?  I know so little about IBC.  I feel so bad for you to have been diagnosed while so very young, but I can tell you are a fighter and I have a feeling that you will do well. Pls free to post any questions for me.  I'll try to answer.  But, again, my memory sucks.  For the first year after my dx, I lived in downtown Detroit, so I had a bit of a drive, too.  Not nearly as long as yours, but I also worked at the Dept. of Veterans Affairs in Ann Arbor, so did the drive nearly everyday of the week.  But then I bought a condo in Ann Arbor and being so close has been great. Please feel to also email me if you like.  Email is judiz@umich.edu Glad the new year is off to a good start.  I hope that 2010 brings you much joy.  Take care. Judi

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2009 06:36PM - edited Dec 30, 2009 07:18PM by Judiiiii MzJoy, Where have you read that B17 is "highly effective as a natural chemotherapy?"  B17 is laetrile and, if you recall, caused quite an uproar many years ago.  It was concluded that it pretty much is a sham.  There is no evidence that laetrile does anything for humans. This is what I've read - on a reputable site: "Most of the websites or magazines promoting laetrile base their claims on unsupported opinions and anecdotal evidence. There IS NOT any evidence that laetrile is an effective treatment for cancer or any other illness. The USA's National Cancer Institute reviews the results of clinical research into the use of laetrile for cancer on its website. One animal study claimed that B17 slowed the growth of cancer in animals and helped stop tumours spreading to the lungs. But repeated studies COULD NOT show similar results, so the treatment remains unproven."  From:  www.cancerhelp.org.uk I'm rather cynical about such things that are described as "highly effective" without seeing the studies - on humans - to back up the claims.  I'd love to see such studies if you have the citations.  Please reference them, if you would.  I'm interested. The only vitamin that I have taken based on human study results of this past summer is Vitamin D.  And I only take the amount that several Vitamin D experts told me was appropriate. One needs to be very, very careful when reviewing the so-called evidence.  The bottom line is that it is always recommended that you read the actual studies upon which "evidence" is based.   Best of luck. Judi Diagnosis: 9/23/2001, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2-

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2009 05:52PM Judiiiii wrote: Toronto, I assume you are in Canada.  Are you, though, looking for a U.S. oncologist?  We don't call them consultants here.  We would be asking for a second opinion if I am understanding your post. I would find one of the NCI-designated Cancer Centers (e.g., MD Anderson in Texas, Johns Hopkins in Baltimore, etc.).  Go to http://cancercenters.cancer.gov/cancer_centers/index.html and check out the centers - there are 23 of them.  Pick one of them and call them and tell them you are seeking a second opinion - either have one of their oncologists faxed her medical records or go in person. Is that what you are looking for?  It probably won't be fast, but please do contact someone at an NCI-designated Cancer Centers.  They are considered the best in the U.S.   Best of luck.  Judi

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2009 08:57PM Judiiiii wrote: Nicole, I hate scans.  Thus, soon after the first year of treatment, I told my onc that he was allowed to scan me once per year.  I have had bone, liver, and lung mets for 8-1/2 years, so it has worked for me.  But the key was that my tumor markers have always been spot on as to what was going on internally and always reliable.  I focused on AST, ALT (although these can change if you stub your toe!), bilirubin, and creatinine.  I don't know what my onc looked at, but he accepted that I directed my care.  He made suggestions, I would research, and I would make the decision.  For example, he suggested Xeloda in combination with Navelbine.  I allowed Xeloda only, not the combo.  Xeloda worked for 4 years by itself and then Navelbine worked for a couple of more years.  So, in effect, by disallowing the combo, I gave myself extra years.  I would spend hours googling and felt I made truly informed decisions.  That's how I've coped - by minimizing situations (e.g., scans) from which I would become super anxious.  Obviously that would not work for everyone.  But at the times that I had to get scanned, I would allow myself a time slot during the day or evening during which I would fret and worry, promising myself that I would not allow the anxiety to take over during all other hours.  Took practice, but it did work for me.  It is rare for a person to be able to eliminate all anxiety, but there are ways to help.  Try "How to Overcome Anxiety for Dummies." Best of luck! Judiiiii

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2009 12:07PM - edited Mar 14, 2009 12:08PM by Judiiiii Lisa, Please make sure that your med onc is always up-to-date on current research regarding ONJ.  I was on monthly Zometa for nearly 6 years - in hindsight, far too often and far too long.  But they were not aware of the possibility of ONJ when I started it in 2001.  ONJ was detected and I have since lost 4 teeth.  I eat eggs and 5 bottles of Ensure daily because I am afraid to chew.  I know that more and more med oncs have a new schedule for Zometa and for this I am very thankful.  I think that the new reduced schedule should help and perhaps hold ONJ at bay  I surely don't mean to scare you, but you and your onc need to be very diligent.  Zometa has a very, very long half life.  I really hesitate posting this, but ONJ has been the worst SE that I have experienced in the nearly 8 years that I have had mets as my initial diagnosis.  I wish I could strike the right balance when telling you to be very diligent without scaring you.  But knowledge is power and if your onc is aware of current studies and recommendations, then I trust that your regimen is aligned with recent study results re ONJ.  Please speak to your onc every now and then regarding what the latest studies re ONJ have shown.  Take care, Lisa.   Judi

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2009 05:53PM Judiiiii wrote: Hi Kimberly, My onc was one of the developers of tumor markers.  Thankfully, they are very, very accurate in my case.  In fact, because of their reliability for me, I allow scans only once per year.  I've had mets for nearly 8 years, but I get tumor markers done each and every time I see the onc - currently once per month.  LuAnn is totally correct, though.  For some patients, tumor markers are worthless.  And, also, while one of my tumor markers might be 50, another patient could have a tumor marker of 775 and yet his/her tumor burden could be similar to mine.  There is also the Cell Search test - similar to tumor markers - also called the circulating tumor cell test - there are a couple of threads on this site about Cell Search (CTC).  I do not think that oncs run the CTC nearly as often as tumor markers, but perhaps they do and just do not discuss the results with their patients.  Not sure.  I've only recently - in the last 4 or 5 months - begun to get the Cell Search done.  I, like LuAnn, always get a copy of my lab results that lists all current and past test results for the past year or so, so that I can refer to it when I want. Take care. P.S.  I also get the CEA - another tumor marker test.   P.P.S.  I'm not a "good little patient" either!!  :>)  I could not be otherwise.  However, after nearly 8 years of mets, I no longer do much research, but I totally agree with LuAnn - oftentimes we must be out own advocate to make sure we are getting the best possible treatment available.  Good luck to you!  Judi
